titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 2029: Instructions for artillery exercises with cannons and mortars.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Instructions for artillery exercises with cannons and mortars, with numbered steps for each exercise. At least one leaf is missing after the frontispiece.

msItem.title: Instructions for artillery exercises with cannons and mortars.
[Instructions for artillery exercises with cannons and mortars]

supportDesc.extent: 73 leaves : 143 x 102 (128 x 82) mm bound to 148 x 110 mm

collation.p: Paper, i (modern paper) + 73 + i (modern paper); singleton frontispiece, 1⁸⁻¹ (leaf 1 missing) 2-8⁸ 9⁸⁺¹ (leaf 9 single); contemporary pagination in ink, modern pagination in pencil, [i-ii], 3-146, upper outer corners.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 20-22 long lines; textblock border-ruled in ink; octavo format.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in semi-cursive script with headings in square capitals.

decoDesc.decoNote: Pen and wash frontispiece of Saint Barbara, patron saint of cannoneers and artillerymen, depicted with martyr's palm and cannon with a domed church in a walled city in the background (p. i); pen and wash cartouches enclosing exercise headings (p. 9, 22, 28, 35, 44, 65, 73, 84, 99, 118, 135); pen and wash vignettes of scallop shells at the end of sections (p. 36, 72); small ink drawing of a seaside scene with buildings and ships at the end of a section; (p. 98); and penwork at the end of sections (p. 34, 44, 64, 66, 71, 83, 98, 146).
Pen and wash drawing, Saint Barbara
Drawing, Landscape with buildings and ships

binding.p: Contemporary (18th-century) limp vellum with two twine clasps and remnants of two thong catches on the fore-edge; modern paper pastedowns and flyleaves.

origin.p: Probably written in Spain in the 18th century.

history.provenance: Sold at auction at Swann Galleries (New York), 18 October 2016, lot 80.

keywords.term: Artillery drill and tactics--Early works to 1800
Military art and science--Early works to 1800
